Zeolite supported nano zero valent iron copper bimetallic composite (Z-nZVFe-16 Cu) was synthesized using an ion exchange method. The morphology and physico-17 chemical properties of the Z-nZVFe-Cu composite were determined using 18 transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), 19 Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET), Energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS), Fourier 20 transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and X-ray diffractometer (XRD). The results 21 showed that iron and copper nano particles were well dispersed on the zeolite sheet. 22 The degradation efficiency of trichloroethylene (TCE) achieved was more than 95% 23 using Z-nZVFe-Cu as a heterogeneous Fenton like catalyst. An efficient removal of 24 total organic carbon (TOC) was promoted as compared to zeolite supported iron nano 25 composite (Z-nZVFe) and unsupported nano iron (nZVFe). Electron spin resonance 26 (ESR) detection confirmed the intensity of hydroxyl radicals (OH●) in the system. 27 While benzoic acid (BA), a probe indicator for the quantification of OH●, 28
demonstrated the higher intensity of hydroxyl radicals in Z-nZVFe-Cu as compared to 29 Z-nZVFe and nZVFe. The less iron and copper leaching of from Z-nZVFe-Cu 30 presented its higher stability and better catalytic activity, displaying its potential long 31 term applications for TCE degradation in groundwater. 32 33 Keywords Sodium percarbonate (SPC); natural zeolite; iron copper bimetals; 34 trichloroethylene (TCE); heterogeneous Fenton catalyst 35 36 1. Introduction 37 Chlorinated organic solvents (COS) such as trichloroethylene (TCE) have been 38 widely used in various industrial processes like dry cleaning and degreasing agent [1]. 39 A huge amount of TCE has been released into the environment owing to the extensive 40 soil and groundwater contamination. TCE has been listed as a priority pollutant that is 41 detected near about 62% of the National Priorities List sites which are regulated by 42 the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) [2]. The human health 43 is adversely affected, causing even cancer due to the chronic exposure to TCE through 44 inhaled vapors released from the contaminated groundwater [3]. Various oxidants like 45 calcium peroxide, persulphate, potassium permanganate, potassium iodate and 46 percarbonate have been employed in in situ chemical oxidation (ISCO). Among these 47 oxidants, sodium percarbonate (SPC) has currently gained attention due to its 48 significant advantages over the conventional Fenton reagents. The SPC decreases the 49 chances of spilling and splashing during transportation and it has significant 50 characteristics of safety, handling, and storage. The SPC develops analogous 51 chemistry like Fenton reagent, i.e. H2O2, and produces environmental friendly by-52 products when introduced into aqueous media. Transition metals like iron can activate 53 SPC as shown in the relevant reactions shown as Eqs. 1-3 [4,5]. 54 2Na2CO3.3H2O2 → 2Na2CO3 + 3H2O2 (1) 55 H2O2 + Fe 2+ → OH● + OH– + Fe3+ (2) 56
Fe3+ + H2O2 → Fe 2+ + HO2 ● + H+ (3) 57 One of the major advantages of the SPC is its compatibility with bioremediation since 58 the products obtained via its decomposition are non-toxic to micro-organisms. Other 59 benefits of SPC include its applicability in a wider range of pH as compared to the 60 optimum pH (3-4) range of the conventional Fenton reagent. When the SPC is mixed 61 in water matrix, H2O2 is produced with no other chemicals which can be considered 62 harmful. The naturally occurring and environmental friendly end products like CO2, 63 H2O and Na2CO3 are produced along with the SPC oxidation. The SPC possesses a 64 base like characteristic that increases the pH of the solution leading towards a 65 buffering effect when SPC is introduced into the solution, since the oxidation of the 66 organic solvents always decreases the pH of the solution [6-9]. On the other hand, the 67 bio-degradation, adsorption, reduction and catalytic oxidation are different 68 remediation techniques that have been used for the remediation of groundwater 69 containing TCE [10,11]. Among current techniques, homogeneous Fenton oxidation 70 is widely used advanced oxidation process for the remediation of groundwater COS 71 [12]. However, the major drawback of the conventional homogeneous Fenton process 72 is the contribution of an enormous amount of iron-salts and their presence in effluents 73 that needs an additional step for the purification of iron containing sludge. In addition, 74 the pH range of the conventional homogeneous Fenton process is 3-4 that further 75 limits its applications [13,14] 76 The heterogeneous Fenton and Fenton like catalysis have been developed as an 77 attractive and promising alternative option in comparison with traditional 78 homogenous Fenton process in order to address the consequences. The main working 79 of the heterogeneous catalysis is to be more effective and stable. Different forms of 80 solid catalysts like iron immobilized iron oxides (magnetite, goethite, ferrihydrite, 81 hematite) [15], iron loaded natural zeolite [16,17] have been used frequently for the 82 activation of H2O2 to generate reactive oxygen species and non-selective hydroxyl 83 radicals (OH●). Such types of heterogeneous catalysts need an additional step of 84
UV/visible light irradiation or ultrasound treatment [18-21] which further increase the 85 cost of water treatment. Even though, the catalytic activities of these heterogeneous 86 catalysts are lower than the conventional homogeneous Fenton reagent (Fe2+). 87 The iron and copper bimetallic catalysis has gained much attention recently. Wang 88 demonstrated an efficient and stable catalytic activity of iron and copper bimetallic 89 nanoparticles embedded within the mesoporous carbon for the remediation of organic 90 contaminants even after five consecutive runs [22]. The catalytic mechanism 91 demonstrated by Wang states that initially Fe0 transforms to Fe2+ through two electron 92 transfer from nano iron surface to H2O2 [17, 21] as shown in Eqs. 4-8. Fe 2+ activates 93 the H2O2 for the production of OH ● radicals by Haber–Weiss mechanism as shown in 94 Eq. 6. The process of simultaneous regeneration of Fe2+ →Fe3+ → Fe2+ may be 95 accomplished via Eq. 8. 96 Fe0 + 2H+ → Fe2+ + H2 (4) 97 Fe0 + H2O2 + 2H + → Fe2+ + 2H2O (5) 98 Fe2++ H2O2 → Fe 3+ + OH● + OH− (6) 99
Fe3+ + H2O2 → Fe 2+ + ●O2H + H + (7) 100 2Fe3+ + Fe0 → 3Fe2+ (8) 101 In the same way, copper may also contribute to activate the SPC for the OH● 102 generation. These reactions might be proceeded as Eqs. 9-11 [23]. 103 Cu+ + H2O2 → Cu 2+ + OH● + OH− (9) 104
Cu2+ + H2O2 → Cu + + ●O2H + OH − (10) 105 Fe3+ + Cu+ → Fe2+ + Cu2+ ∆E0 = 0.6V (11) 106 Han also showed that copper and iron bimetal amidoximated polyacrylonitrile 107 (PAN) fiber complexes effectively catalyzed Rhodamine B with H2O2 [24]. Similarly, 108 Dükkancı [25] and Xia [26] also synthesized iron and copper bimetallic catalysts and 109 found higher catalytic activity and stability for the degradation of Rhodamine 6G and 110 phenol respectively (A highly active bimetallic oxides catalyst supported on Al-111 containing MCM-41 for Fenton oxidation of phenol solution). Timofeeva also 112
confirmed the efficient catalytic efficiency of iron copper aluminum clays [27]. Our 113 research group reported a heterogeneous Fenton like zeolite supported nano zero 114 valent iron (Z-nZVFe) composite for the catalytic degradation of the TCE. The TCE 115 degradation efficiency was relatively high but no significant degradation was 116 achieved using only Z-nZVFe. However, addition of reducing agents increased the 117 TCE degradation significantly [28,29]. 118 The enhancement in the dispersion of the heterogeneous Fenton like catalysts and 119 inhibition of severe aggregation are the two key parameters to achieve an efficient 120 catalytic efficiency [30]. Porous materials just like mesoporous carbon [22], reduced 121 graphene oxide [31], active carbon [15], multi walled carbon nano tubes [32], zeolite 122 [28] and mesoporous silica [33] have been developed as supporting materials to 123 achieve an efficient degradation of contaminants. A relatively cheaper cost of the 124 natural zeolite stipulates mass applications due to its abundant availability. In 125 addition, natural zeolite is a potential support material due to its catalyzing action, 126 adsorption capacity, thermal stability and strong resistance in various chemical 127 environments [34]. The heterogeneous catalysts incorporation on the natural zeolite 128 sheet follows two types of approaches, i.e. ion exchanged approach and hydrothermal 129 process. However, the catalyst prepared from hydrothermal process has lower 130 catalytic ability due to less loading of metals (copper and iron) on the zeolite sheet as 131 compared to the catalyst prepared by ion exchanged process [25] which may further 132 lowers the stability of the catalyst due to weak interaction between metallic particles 133 and supporting materials. On the other hand, the catalysts prepared by ion exchanged 134 procedure have effective catalytic activities and stability [16]. Moreover, fine particles 135 of copper and iron were well dispersed on zeolite sheet leading towards more 136 enhanced catalytic activity. 137 In this study, we synthesized and characterized zeolite supported iron and copper 138 bimetallic nano particles composite (Z-nZVFe-Cu). The ion exchange along with in 139 situ reduction strategy was adopted to synthesize Z-nZVFe-Cu composite. The 140
catalytic activity of the composite was evaluated by choosing TCE as a model 141 chlorinated organic contaminant. To the best of our knowledge, so far there is no 142 related documents reported using Z-nZVFe-Cu catalyst to activate SPC in TCE 143 degradation research. For the comparison of catalysts performance, the Z-nZVFe and 144 the unsupported-nZVFe were synthesized using the identical route. Further, the study 145 could be used to elucidate the combined effects of iron and copper on the natural 146 zeolite sheet for the degradation of groundwater contaminant, e.g. the TCE. 147
2. Materials and methods 148
2.1 Materials and chemicals 149 Trichloroethylene (TCE, 99.0%) was purchased from Shanghai Jingchun Reagent 150 Ltd. Co. (Shanghai, China). Ethanol (99.0%), ferrous sulfate heptahydrate (99.8%), 151 sodium chloride (99.0%), sodium percarbonate (SPC, 98.5%), benzoic acid (BA), and 152 aluminosilicates (99.0%) were acquired from Acros Organics (Shanghai, China). 153 Copper sulphate heptahydrate (99.0%), potassium iodide (98%), potassium bromide 154 (99%), sodium sulphate (99%), monopotassium phosphate (98.5%), n-hexane 155 (99.0%), 5,5-dimethylpyrroline-1-oxide (DMPO) and 5,5-potassium biphthalate 156 (99.5%) were obtained from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). The ultra-pure milli-Q water 157 was mixed in amber flask with TCE to get stock solution of 0.15 mM concentration. 158 0.1 M of NaOH and HCl were used for adjusting the solution pH. No further 159 purification was done for all the reagents used in experimentations. The milli-Q ultra-160 pure water process (classic DI, ELGA, 102 Marlow, U.K.) was used to get deionized 161 water which was used in all experiments. 162
2.2 Preparation of the zeolite supported iron-copper bimetallic nano-composite 163 The zeolite supported iron-copper bimetallic nano composite (Z-nZVFe-Cu) was 164 synthesized using ion exchanged procedure. In a preparation of the Z-nZVFe-Cu 165 composite, 1.0 g of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 0.025 g of copper sulphate 166
heptahydrate and 0.5 g of aluminosilicates (natural zeolite) were mixed in 300 mL of 167 ultra-pure water. The pH of the solution was adjusted using HCl to near 4 in avoiding 168 any effect on the stability of the zeolite and oxidation of iron or copper. This mixture 169 was kept on ultrasound for 30 min, then this mixture was stirred continuously for 170 another 30 min. Due to the hydrolysis of the zeolite, pH was slightly increased but it 171 remained below 5 during the reaction time. This aqueous solution was filtered using a 172 filer paper of 47 mm diameter with the pore size of 0.45 µm and the remaining solids 173 were placed in a three neck flask containing 50 mL of deionized and deoxygenated 174 water. Sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 1.0 M) was used drop wise to get a high level of 175 reduction of exchanged iron and copper ions in a nitrogen atmosphere. The blackish 176 particles appeared on the very first drop of NaBH4 and were separated from a 47 mm 177 diameter filter membrane after the completion of the reaction. The black particles 178 were washed twice with water and ethanol respectively to eliminate all traces of 179 sulphate ions and vacuum dried for 24 hours. 180
Fe2+ + 2BH4  ̶ + 6H2O → Fe 0 + 2B (OH) 3 + 7H2 (12) 181
Cu2+ + 2BH4 ̶ + 6H2O → Cu 0 + 2B (OH) 3 + 7H2 (13) 182
For the comparison, the Z-nZVFe and the unsupported nZVFe were synthesized using 183 the identical procedure. 184
2.3 Characterization of zeolite supported iron-copper bimetallic nano-composite 185 The morphology of prepared catalysts was obtained by transmission electron 186 microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100 electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage 187 at 200 kV). XRD diffraction patterns were recorded by X-ray diffractometer (XRD) 188 along with Rigaku D/max diffractometer (2550 VB/PC; CuKα (λ =0.154 nm 189 radiation). Nitrogen adsorption desorption isotherms were obtained using Brunauer–190 Emmett–Teller (BET) method (Quantasorb Jr. Instrument Quantachrome Co. UK) to 191 find particle size, total pore volume, specific surface area and pore size of the 192
prepared catalysts. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of samples 193 were obtained using a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet 6700, Thermo Fisher Scientific, 194 4000-400 cm-1) with a scan no of 32 and spectral resolution of 4 cm-1. Potassium 195 bromide (KBr) was calcined at 600ºC for six hours in a muffle furnace for the purpose 196 of removing organic impurities before testing. Elemental composition of the prepared 197 catalysts was obtained using energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS). 198 199 2.4 Experimental procedures 200 Standard solution of 0.15 mM concentration of TCE was prepared by allowing the 201 pure non-aqueous phase liquid TCE to equilibrate with ultra-pure water for 60 min 202 with gentle stirring. All prepared catalysts were dried in vacuum at 100ºC before 203 using in the experiments. To achieve the adsorption-desorption equilibrium between 204 TCE and catalyst, the solution was stirred vigorously for one hour without the 205 addition of SPC. A cylindrical glass reactor (250 mL) with two openings at the top 206 having inner diameter of 6.0 cm and height of 9.0 cm was used for the test of 207 degradation of TCE. One main opening at the top of the reactor was used for dosing 208 purpose and the other opening for sampling purpose. The temperature of the reactor 209 was controlled at 20 ± 0.5ºC through the double jacket of the reactor by circulating 210 the external thermostatic water by using temperature bath (DC Ningbo, China). The 211 required amounts of all the reagents were added sequentially into the reactor 212 containing TCE and a magnetic stirrer was also inserted into the reactor for 213 homogeneous mixing of the reagents. The pH of solutions were adjusted by using (0.1 214 M) HCl and recorded with pH meter. Samples were taken at the required time 215 intervals and analyzed with gas chromatography (GC) using n-hexane as a solvent 216 extractor. Furthermore, for OH● quantification, a 3.0 mL volume of the samples were 217 collected and filtered through an ultra-four centrifuge ultrafilter with a nominal pore 218 size of 1-2 nm to remove particles from the samples along with 30 min of 219 centrifugation [35]. A high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was used for 220
the degradation of a probe indicator (BA) to quantify OH● coupled with plasma-mass 221 spectrometry and DLS to further verify the undissolved particles in the filtrate. Total 222 organic carbon (TOC) were measured using TOC analyzer and all the samples were 223 treated with scavenging agent (0.1 M KI, 0.05 M NaOH, 0.1 M KH2PO4 and 0.1 224 Na2SO3) to get an accurate TOC value [36]. All experiments were conducted twice 225 and average values reported here. 226
2.5 Analytical methods 227 One milliliter samples of TCE at desired time intervals were extracted with equal 228 volume of n-hexane and stirred with a vortex stirrer and then waiting for 5 min to get 229 samples to analyze with gas chromatograph (Agilent GC 7890A, Palo Alto, CA, 230 USA). The oven, injector and detector (ECD) temperatures were maintained at 75ºC, 231 240ºC, and 260ºC respectively. The degradation of the benzoic acid (BA) that was 232 used as a probe indicator to quantify the OH● radicals was measured by using Varian 233 Prostar 310 HPLC instrument equipped with a column (4.6 × 150 × 0.005 mm), 234 mobile phase of methanol/deionized water mixture (55/45, v/v) and UV detector 235 operated at 237 nm [37]. To get accurate TOC values, the samples were immediately 236 quenched with scavenging agent, i.e. sodium sulphate (0.1 M), by using a multi 3100 237 TOC-TN analyzer. The use of these scavenging agents lead towards the complete 238 reduction of SPC, i.e. H2O2 and discharge of the present iron ions as these scavenging 239 agents act as precipitation and reduction agents [36,38]. Electron spin resonance 240 (ESR) spectra was obtained using EMX-8/2.7C, Bruker, Germany with Microwave 241 Bridge (microwave frequency 9.866 GHz, conversion time, 40.96 ms, field sweep 100 242 G, microwave power 2.016 mW, time constant 163.84 ms, number of scans, 1 and 243 modulation amplitude 1 G. One milliliter of the samples were collected and 244 immediately mixed with 1.0 mL of the DMPO (8.84 mM) for one minute to form 245 DMPO-OH● adduct to elucidate the generation of hydroxyl radicals. The iron and 246 copper leaching was measured by using inductively coupled plasma-mass 247 spectrometer (ICP-MS, Agilent 7500ce, Agilent Technologies, CA). The pH of the 248
solution was measured by using pH meter (Mettler Toledo DELTA 320, Greifensee, 249 Switzerland). 250
3. Results and discussions 251
3.1 Physico-chemical properties and morphology of zeolite supported iron-252 copper bimetallic nano-composite 253
The morphologies of the natural zeolite, unsupported-nZVFe, Z-nZVFe and Z-254 nZVFe-Cu are observed by SEM and TEM as shown in Fig. 1. The natural zeolite has 255 a smooth surface while the surfaces of nZVFe, Z-nZVFe and Z-nZVFe-Cu are 256 abrasive. It is observed that unsupported-nZVFe and Z-nZVFe particles have quasi-257 spherical shape [28] and uneven shape, respectively, whereas Z-nZVFe-Cu particles 258 have mostly spherical and core shell structure shape. The TEM image (Fig. 1b) is 259 viewed along the facet [0 0 1] and Fig. 1c is viewed along the facet [1 1 0]. The 260 incorporation of iron and copper bimetallic nano-particles is clearly visible in the 261 form of dark spots enclosed in a shell which are significantly dispersed over the entire 262 sheet of natural zeolite. The particle size distribution showed that the average size of 263 iron-copper bimetallic nano-particles are among 10-30 nm. The morphology of the 264 reused Z-nZVFe-Cu is shown in Fig. S1 showing the prolonged sustainability 265 characteristics of spherical and core like structure of the Z-nZVFe-Cu particles. 266
Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was performed to determine the contents 267 of iron, copper, and zeolite. It is clear from Fig. 2 that zeolite did not contain any 268 amount of iron whereas, the Z-nZVFe-Cu has maximum amount of iron loading than 269 the nZVFe and the Z-nZVFe. The mass ratio of iron and copper is 0.29 that is 270 significant proportion of the theoretical value of 0.39. The EDX of the reused Z-271 nZVFe-Cu also showed the presence of significant amount of iron and copper in the 272 framework of natural zeolite as shown in Table 1. 273
The data of the surface characteristics of all the prepared catalysts and reused Z-274 nZVFe-Cu were determined using N2- adsorption-desorption isotherms as are shown 275 in Table 1. A relatively wide pore size distribution was confirmed by calculating pore 276 size distribution curves using desorption-isotherms branches. It is also observed that 277 N2-filling occurred at about P/P0= 0.52–0.98, showing homogeneity of zeolite sheet 278 pore sizes due to capillary condensation. The zeolite sheet has a BET surface area of 279 0.60 m2/g whereas, zeolite supported ion exchanged iron and copper particles have a 280 BET surface area of 87.06 m2/g. The BET surface area of nZVFe and Z-nZVFe are 281 relatively smaller, i. e. 21.51 m2/g and 72.2 m2/g, respectively. The average pore size 282 of Z-nZVFe-Cu is 17.94 nm whereas, the values for zeolite, nZVFe and Z-nZVFe 283 have are 7.12, 9.03 and 13.84 nm, respectively. The significant increase in the BET 284 surface area and the average pore size of Z-nZVFe-Cu assures the robust phenomena 285 of ion exchanged iron and copper on the zeolite sheet. The entrapping of iron and 286 copper on the zeolite sheet mired the aluminosilicates shrinkage which may be a 287 further reason behind the increased BET surface area and pore size of the Z-nZVFe-288 Cu. It was observed that decrease in the BET surface area, pore volume and pore 289 diameter of the reused Z-nZVFe-Cu was very minute showing the enhanced catalytic 290 ability of the Z-nZVFe-Cu for the extended applications due to non-aggregation of the 291 iron and copper on natural zeolite support. Our previously published report have 292 stated that the increased surface area and pore size of the particles are due to non-293 aggregation of particles [28,29]. 294
Wide angle X-ray diffraction (WA-XRD) configurations of zeolite sheet and the 295 prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 3. The zeolite has crystalline structure showing 296 largely prominent and sharp multiple diffraction peaks centered at 2θ = 19.1, 21.5, 297 23.8, 27.8, 29.9, 32.1, 33.7 and 39.4 corresponding to the reflections of 298 aluminosilicates. The WA-XRD of unsupported nZVFe showed two diffraction peaks 299 centered at 26.1 and 44.9 owing to the body centered cubic ά-Fe0. The WA-XRD of 300 the Z-nZVFe showed gloomy peaks at 23.86, 25.75, 36.21, and 27.80 showing the 301
presence of lepidocrocite and maghemite (γ-Fe2O3) (JCPDS card # 89-5892) while the 302 sharp peak at 43.1 is most likely due to the presence of FeO [28]. On the other hand, 303 the WA-XRD pattern of the Z-nZVFe-Cu diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32.8, 38.5 and 304 77.4 were most likely due to the formation of CuFeO2 and Fe3C (JCPDS card # 87-305 0721) whereas, the peaks at 43.9 and 64.2 may be contributing to the iron [22]. It is 306 observed that the lepidocrocite and maghemite diffraction peaks of Z-nZVFe were 307 disappeared and the new peaks of CuFeO2 and Fe3C appeared with a positive shift in 308 the Z-nZVFe-Cu. The crystallite size of the Z-nZVFe-Cu particles was 36 nm 309 measured by Scherer equation [39]. It is important to note that the intensity of the 310 diffraction peaks of the Z-nZVFe-Cu increased as compared to the Z-nZVFe and 311 nZVFe which might be due to the strong interaction of iron and copper particles on 312 the zeolite sheet by decreasing the reduction temperature of the iron. The WA-XRD 313 of the reused Z-nZVFe-Cu did not show any severe disappearance of the iron and 314 copper peaks with almost negligible shifts as shown in Fig. S2, showing the enhanced 315 stability and catalytic ability of the reused Z-nZVFe-Cu. Moreover, the results also 316 indicated that the diffraction peaks of the zeolite disappeared owing to the presence of 317 the iron and copper nanoparticles on its framework. 318
The FT-IR differential spectrum of the zeolite and Z-nZVFe-Cu were recorded as 319 shown in Fig. 4. The internal group bands characteristic for the zeolite near 465, 685 320 and 1105 are due to the internal vibration of the stretching, bending and rocking of the 321 Al-O-Si bridge whereas, the other group bands are related to the external vibrations. It 322 is also interpreted that the group band near 565 is due to the D4R (double four rings) 323 which is significant in natural zeolite structure whereas, the group band near 390 is 324 assigned to the lattice vibrations [40]. The regions from 1200 to 1600 are assigned to 325 the cations [41]. On the other side, Z-nZVFe-Cu spectra obtained shows that no 326 significant change observed as compared to the parent natural zeolite except the 327 appearance of the additional characteristics group bands of iron and copper. The 328 spectra peak near 532.8 is due to the iron, whereas, the peaks near 541.2 and 548.5 are 329
corresponding to the iron oxide and sulfite nanoparticles respectively. The 330 characteristic group band peaks from 3200 to 3600 are assigned to the –OH stretching 331 [42]. The presence of copper was observed with a mode near 990 due to the Si-O-Cu 332 stretching [43]. 333
3.2 Degradation performance of trichloroethylene in Z-nZVFe-Cu-percarbonate 334 system 335
The catalytic activity and performance of the prepared Z-nZVFe-Cu composite 336 was determined by degrading one of the most toxic chlorinated organic model 337 contaminants, i.e. trichloroethylene (TCE). Various experiments were conducted to 338 degrade TCE using Z-nZVFe-Cu, previously prepared zeolite loaded nano iron 339 composite (Z-nZVFe) [28], nano zero valent iron (nZVFe), natural zeolite (Z), copper 340 (Cu) and oxidant (SPC) for the purpose of comparison, and the control tests were also 341 performed in the absence of percarbonate and other catalysts. The TCE adsorption 342 was measured before examining the degradation of TCE in various catalysts systems. 343 The suspension was stirred continually for one hour in order to achieve the 344 adsorption-desorption equilibrium between the TCE and catalysts before SPC 345 addition. The TCE adsorption in the case of Z-nZVFe-Cu as a catalyst is 21.4% that 346 shows its adsorption characteristics (Fig. 5). Equilibrium achieved was confirmed in 347 one hour because no significant difference was found in the next hour as depicted in 348 the Fig. S3 (profile with time). The adsorption characteristics of the Z-nZVFe-Cu are 349 related to the large pore size (10 nm) and higher BET surface area (87 m2/g). The 350 TCE adsorption is 15.8%, 7.5%, 9.8% and 3.2% when Z-nZVFe, nZVFe, Cu and 351 zeolite, respectively, were used instead of Z-nZVFe-Cu. A relatively slow and much 352 less TCE decrease is observed when only SPC was added to the system showing its 353 weak oxidation potential than hydroxyl radicals (OH●). 354
However, an efficient degradation of TCE (95%) is achieved when catalyzed by 355 Z-nZVFe-Cu with dosage of 200 mg/L, indicating the higher catalytic capability of 356 SPC activation as shown in Fig. 6. On the other hand, the TCE degradation 357 efficiencies catalyzed by Z-nZVFe, nZVFe, Cu and SPC are 63.7%, 48%, 39.2% and 358 2.54%, respectively, showing less catalytic activity than Z-nZVFe-Cu in the same 359 experimental conditions as shown in Fig. 6. For further comparison, the catalytic 360 activity of Z-nZVFe-Cu was also observed with previously reported [28] catalyst 361 dosage of 100 mg/L (Fig .7). It is observed that degradation of TCE was more 362 efficient with Z-nZVFe-Cu (65.4%) rather than Z-nZVFe (39.2%). From the data 363 shown in Figs. 6 and 7, the SPC alone is unable to degrade TCE significantly 364 whereas, Z-nZVFe degraded TCE higher than nZVFe and Cu alone but still not 365 completely which might be due to aggregation of nano-iron particles with a relatively 366 small BET surface area (72 m2/g). The enhanced degradation of the TCE is due to the 367 improved physico-chemical properties of the Z-nZVFe-Cu including BET surface 368 area, average pore diameter and average particle diameter due to the effect of both 369 iron and copper supported on the natural zeolite sheet. The highly dispersed nano-370 particles of the iron and copper on zeolite sheet increased the active sites leading 371 towards higher catalytic ability for SPC activation. Moreover, the enhanced catalytic 372 activity of Z-nZVFe-Cu might be due to strong metal support interaction (SMSI) of 373 the both metals [44]. The subsequent reactions occurred on the surface of zeolite with 374 active sites. The larger pore size of the Z-nZVFe-Cu can minimize the resistance of 375 mass transfer of the products and reactants that ensured an efficient and enhanced 376 catalytic activity. In comparison with Z-nZVFe, nZVFe and Cu, Z-nZVFe-Cu 377 demonstrated a significant increase in efficiency for percarbonate activation. 378
In order to further investigate the reaction kinetics of TCE degradation, pseudo 379 first order kinetic equation was used as a model equation. This kinetic equation can be 380 expressed as Eq. 14: 381
-ln (Ci/Co) = k t (14) 382 Where Ci and Co are concentrations of TCE at initial and at time (t) and k is the 383 apparent rate constant which can be calculated from the slope of the line by plotting -384 ln (Ci/C0) versus t (min). The regression lines can be achieved by plotting -ln (Ci/C0) 385 against t (min) with a correlation coefficient (R2) of 0.907 and 0.994 respectively as 386 shown in Fig. 8. The kinetic analysis confirmed that TCE degradation follows the 387 pseudo first order as shown in Fig. 8. The apparent reaction rate constants of Z-388 nZVFe-Cu and Z-nZVFe were 1.02 and 0.27 hr-1 respectively, which is almost four 389 folds difference. The rate of TCE degradation was closely linked to the initial 390 concentration of TCE and the active surface sites of Z-nZVI and Z-nZVI-Cu. [45]. 391 The evaluation of the higher rate constant of Z-nZVFe-Cu clearly indicated that it has 392 significantly higher catalytic ability than the Z-nZVFe. Addition of second metal (Cu) 393 may be another reason behind the significant increment in the rate constant of Z-394 nZVFe-Cu as compared to Z-nZVFe because all the conditions in synthesizing both 395 catalyst composites were the same. These kinetic study results are validating the 396 higher catalytic efficiency of Z-nZVFe-Cu than Z-nZVFe for the degradation of TCE 397 as discussed above. A study conducted by Wang also demonstrated that addition of 398 second metal on the mesoporous carbon support produced an enhanced effect due to 399 which rate constant increased four folds and the degradation of bisphenol A occurred 400 at a faster rate [22]. 401
Several experimental conditions were applied to evaluate the TCE degradation 402 with respect to reaction time. The influence of initial parameters just like Z-nZVFe-403 Cu dosages and SPC concentration were also studied in order to find their 404 contributions in the TCE degradation. It can be seen from Fig. 9 that TCE degradation 405 rate was significantly increased when Z-nZVFe-Cu dosage was increased from 100 406 mg/L to 200 mg/L but further increase in Z-nZVFe-Cu dosage could not have 407 significant effect on TCE degradation. For instance, TCE degradation was increased 408 from 57.7% to 97.8%, 98.7% and 99.8% when dosages were 100, 200, 300 and 400 409
mg/L respectively. No significant difference is observed in TCE degradation in the 410 case of excess dosages of Z-nZVFe-Cu, i.e. 300 and 400 mg/L. Therefore, the loading 411 of 200 mg/L was taken as an ideal loading for the rest of experiments due to the 412 following reasons. The first reason was usage of low amount of the catalyst as 413 compared to other loadings with almost same degradation efficiency in the same 414 interval of time and the second reason was the price of the catalyst that was taken into 415 consideration. The higher Z-nZVFe-Cu dosage increased the available surface of 416 catalyst leading towards the more reaction sites availability. 417
The influence of SPC concentration on the catalytic efficiency of Z-nZVFe-Cu 418 was also elucidated. The theoretical stoichiometric molar ratio of SPC for complete 419 mineralization of TCE is 2 as shown in Eq. 15 [46]. Therefore, 0.3 mM SPC can 420 completely mineralize 0.15 mM of TCE. 421
C2HCl3 + 2Na2CO3•1.5H2O2 (s) → Na2CO3 + 3Cl ̶ +H++ 2Na+ + 3CO2 (g) + 3H2O 422 (15) 423
The concentrations of SPC chosen in this study are 0.3, 1.0, 5.0 and 10 mM. As 424 shown in Fig. 10, it was observed that the TCE degradation was significantly 425 increased by increasing the SPC concentrations from 0.3 to 5.0 mM but further 426 increase to 10 mM decreased the TCE degradation. For instance, the TCE degradation 427 decreased from 99.8% to 78.2% when SPC concentration increased from 5.0 to 10 428 mM. However, there was no significant difference of TCE degradation from 1.0 to 5.0 429 mM (98 to 99.8%) in the same interval of time. Therefore, 1.0 mM was taken as 430 optimum SPC concentration in this study. This is a similar phenomena to Fenton like 431 reactions, i.e. increasing the concentration of H2O2 increases the degradation of 432 organic contaminants to a certain level but further increase in concentrations makes it 433 less effective or inefficient [47]. The decrease in TCE degradation due to the 434 excessive SPC addition might be due to scavenging effect of hydrogen peroxide that 435
can be described by Eqs. 16-17. Actually, our previous studies suggested that higher 436 concentrations of H2O2 in the Fenton system proceed quenching reactions leading 437 towards consumption of OH● [5,9]. 438
H2O2 + OH ● → H2O + OOH ● (16) 439
OOH● + OH● → H2O + O2 (17) 440
3.3 Possible catalytic mechanism 441
In order to understand the reaction mechanism, electron paramagnetic resonance 442 (EPR) studies were conducted to examine the production of hydroxyl radicals (OH●) 443 in the Z-nZVFe-Cu, Z-nZVFe, nZVFe and zeolite catalyzed percarbonate systems as 444 shown in Fig. 11. The 5,5-dimethylpyrroline-1-oxide (DMPO) was used as hydroxyl 445 radical adduct. No signal of DMPO-OH● adduct for zeolite is found, showing its least 446 catalytic ability for the activation of SPC. However, the rest of three EPR spectra 447 exhibited four folds characteristic peak with peak intensity ratios of 1:2:2:1. It is 448 obvious that Z-nZVFe and nZVFe can activate SPC to produce OH● radicals but the 449 characteristic peak height ratio of the DMPO-OH● adduct using Z-nZVFe-Cu as a 450 catalyst is significantly higher than Z-nZVFe and nZVFe. The results clearly indicated 451 that Z-nZVFe-Cu exhibited significantly high catalytic ability than other catalysts. 452 The EPR spectrum for OH● obtained in our study is consistent with the previously 453 published reports [22]. 454 As far as we know, EPR spectrum could show the relative intensity of OH● 455 strength but not the quantitative concentration of OH●. In order to determine the 456 generation of OH● radicals quantitatively, benzoic acid (BA) was used as a probe 457 indicator that has a known reaction rate constant of 4.2 × 109 M-1s-1 with OH● radicals 458 in the aqueous medium by using HPLC [35]. The reaction of BA with OH● radicals 459 produce p-hydroxybenzoic acid (p-HBA), o-hydroxybenzoic acid (o-HBA), m- 460 hydroxybenzoic acid (m-HBA) and other products. Zhou and Mopper reported that 461
5.87 ± 18 moles of OH● reacts with one mole of p-HBA produced [48]. The 462 consumption of the OH● radicals induced by the other side reactions is considered 463 negligible [49]. It was observed that the degradation of p-HBA by using Z-nZVFe-Cu 464 as a catalyst was significantly higher (92.1%) than Z-nZVFe and unsupported-nZVFe 465 corresponding to 56.9% and 45.8% of p-HBA degradation respectively as shown in 466 Fig. 12a. The obtained results clearly indicated that OH● generation is significant in 467 Z-nZVFe-Cu catalyzed SPC system and it is also persistent with the trend of TCE 468 degradation. The average molar concentration of the OH● radicals can be computed 469 from the corresponding p-HBA curve by 470
C = − / T (18) 471
Where, C is the average molar concentration of OH● radicals, Ci is the initial 472 molar concentration and Co is the final molar concentration of the p-HBA after a time 473 of t (h) and T is the total exposure time of 3 h. The quantity of generated OH● radicals 474 by Z-nZVFe-Cu was 375 µM that is approximately more than two folds to Z-nZVFe 475 (169 µM), 3.75 folds to nZVFe (99.8 µM), 5.2 folds to Cu (72.1 µM) and 18.75 folds 476 to SPC (20 µM) respectively as shown in Fig. 12b. The enhanced OH● generation in 477 Z-nZVFe-Cu is most likely due to the increased surface area of the Z-nZVFe-Cu 478 providing more active sites for catalytic activity [50]. It can be concluded from the 479 above results that OH● is playing the main role as an oxidizing reactive species in the 480 Z-nZVFe-Cu system. In addition, copper may contribute in the stability of iron [22]. 481
The proposed catalytic mechanism is based on the EPR, p-HBA degradation and 482 XRD results obtained. The apparent rate constant of the Z-nZVFe-Cu for the 483 degradation of p-HBA was 0.84 hr-1 that was 3.8 and 5.3 folds greater than the rate 484 constants of Z-nZVFe and nZVFe respectively. The enhanced rate constant of the Z-485 nZVFe-Cu depends on the various parameters such as pore size, pore diameter, 486 particle size, surface area, interaction between iron and copper and the role of zeolite 487 as a support material. The combinational effect of all these parameters is inhibiting 488
the aggregation of particles and increasing the number of available sites for reactions. 489 The reactions catalyzed by Z-nZVFe-Cu proceed through surface reactions involving 490 the active sites of zero valent iron and copper. The reduction potential of Cu+2/Cu+ 491 and Fe3+/Fe2+ are 0.17 V and 0.77 V, respectively. The reduction of ferric through 492 copper is advantageous thermodynamically and beneficial for the reduction and 493 oxidation reactions of Cu+2/Cu+ and Fe3+/Fe2+. The interfacial electron transfer 494 significantly increased in Z-nZVFe-Cu due to the contribution of both Cu+2/Cu+ and 495 Fe3+/Fe2+ pairs. Hence, Z-nZVFe-Cu exhibited significant catalytic activity for the 496 TCE degradation owing to the combined effects of both iron and copper on the natural 497 zeolite sheet. 498
3.4 Total organic carbon (TOC) removal and dechlorination of TCE 499
The TOC removal was investigated using the TOC analyzer to elucidate the 500 mineralization of TCE in the presence of SPC activated by Z-nZVFe-Cu. According 501 to the stoichiometric Eq. 1, one mole of TCE has to consume two moles of SPC for 502 the complete mineralization of TCE, therefore, 0.3 mM SPC is required to mineralize 503 0.15 mM of TCE completely. The results clearly indicated that TOC removal was 504 12.2% when 0.3 mM SPC was used corresponding to the 20% TCE degradation as 505 shown in Fig. 13a. This low removal of TOC might be due to the low concentration of 506 SPC in aqueous solution. Further increase in SPC concentration to 1.0 mM increased 507 TOC removal significantly to 75.2% corresponding to the 98% TCE degradation. The 508 SPC concentration was increased to 5.0 mM for further increase in TOC removal 509 which resulted in 83.8% with almost complete TCE degradation. However, increase 510 in SPC concentration to 10 mM decreased the TOC removal to 41% which is also in 511 accordance to the declined TCE degradation results. Due to the transformation of 512 metallic iron and copper of the Z-nZVFe-Cu by oxidation to their corresponding 513 cations, change in physico-chemical properties was expected. Therefore, TOC 514 removal was also elucidated in the case of the second run of Z-nZVFe-Cu as shown in 515
the Fig. 13b. It was observed that TOC removal was 9.2, 69.45, 76.58 and 35.21% 516 with SPC concentrations of 0.3, 1.0, 5.0 and 10 mM respectively. The results clearly 517 indicated that the reused Z-nZVFe-Cu still have significant capability for TOC 518 removal. Moreover, the influence of various loadings of Z-nZVFe-Cu (100, 200, 300 519 and 400 mg/L) were also analyzed for the TOC removal as shown in the Fig. S4. It 520 was observed that TOC removal rate significantly increased from 57.8 to 78.9 % 521 when Z-nZVFe-Cu loading increased from 100 to 200 mg/L. However, no significant 522 increase in TOC removal was observed when Z-nZVFe-Cu loadings reached 300 and 523 400 mg/L. The rate constants and R2 values for all loadings of Z-nZVFe-Cu for TOC 524 removal are listed in Table. S1 to confirm the heterogeneous nature of the Z-nZVFe-525 Cu and pseudo first order behavior. 526
TCE dechlorination efficiency was also measured for identical concentrations of 527 SPC which were used for TOC removal as shown in Fig. 14. The addition of 0.3 mM 528 SPC liberated 0.029 mM chloride ions (Cl−) accounted for 9.8% of the TCE 529 dechlorination efficiency, to some extent less than 12.2% TOC removal. Increasing 530 SPC concentration to 1.0 and 5.0 mM increased the release of Cl− to 0.195 and 0.218 531 mM corresponding to the TCE dechlorination efficiency of 65.2% and 72.8% 532 respectively. Further increase in the SPC concentration to 10 mM decreased the 533 release of Cl− to 0.104 mM. The liberation of the total amount of Cl− indicated 72.8% 534 dechlorination efficiency of TCE with 83.8% of TOC removal. Further investigations 535 by GC-MS confirmed the existence of formic acid, oxalic acid, and glyoxylic acid as 536 intermediate products which were finally transformed into the carbon dioxide, water, 537 chloride ions and hydrogen ions at the end of the reaction. It is suggested that some 538 chlorinated products were also present as intermediate products but not detected due 539 to the lower concentrations. The hydroxyl radicals (OH●) play major role in TCE 540 degradation suggesting its possible pathway. Initially, the OH● attack the C2 of TCE 541 to generate aliphatic compounds like formic acid, oxalic acid, and glyoxylic which 542
were further transformed to carbon dioxide, water, chloride ions and hydrogen ions. 543 Similar results were obtained by our other previous groups [10]. 544
3.5 Stability, recyclability and leaching of Z-nZVFe-Cu 545
The long term stability and recyclability of the catalysts are the consistent 546 problems in heterogeneous catalysis. The variation in activity performance and 547 leaching characteristics of the Z-nZVFe-Cu were elaborated from view point of the 548 actual applications. Iron and copper in leachates determined by inductively coupled 549 plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) demonstrated that the concentrations of total 550 dissolved iron and copper were 0.30 mg/L and 0.015 mg/L in the absence of SPC and 551 0.59 mg/L and 0.029 mg/L in the presence of SPC respectively. The less leaching of 552 iron and copper confirms the enhanced stability of the Z-nZVFe-Cu that might be due 553 to the strong interaction between the iron and copper on the natural zeolite sheet. 554 Additionally, to elucidate the possibility of the re-usage of the Z-nZVFe-Cu for the 555 degradation of TCE, a set of experiment was conducted as shown in Fig. 15. It is 556 observed that the efficiencies for the TCE degradation were significantly higher after 557 even four consecutive runs confirming remarkable catalytic ability of the Z-nZVFe-558 Cu. These results further confirmed that the nano zero valent iron and copper 559 supported on the framework of the natural zeolite significantly extended the life of Z-560 nZVFe-Cu. 561 Conclusion 562 In this study, we have demonstrated natural zeolite supported iron-copper 563 bimetallic nanoparticles composite (Z-nZVFe-Cu) as a catalyst. The Z-nZVFe-Cu was 564 synthesized using wet ion exchanged method. The TEM and WA-XRD analysis 565 showed the distribution of the iron and copper bimetallic nanoparticles on the sheet of 566 zeolite. The significantly enhanced degradation of TCE was achieved using Z-nZVFe-567 Cu as a heterogeneous catalyst. The TOC removal and mineralization of TCE by 568 using the Z-nZVFe-Cu (200 mg/L) as a catalyst was maximum with 1.0 and 5.0 mM 569
SPC at the same conditions. On the other hand, when the concentration of SPC was 570 further increased, an inhibitive trend of TOC removal was observed which was 571 consistent with TCE degradation. The main advantage of Z-nZVFe-Cu composite is 572 its higher surface area which enabled the diffusion of reactants and products rapidly. 573 Another advantage is the increment in the active sites due to the dispersal of iron-574 copper bimetallic nanoparticles on the natural zeolite sheet. The third advantage of the 575 Z-nZVFe-Cu is the combined effect of iron-copper bimetallic nanoparticles which 576 might favor the reduction and oxidation of Fe3+ to Fe2+ and Cu2+ to Cu+ in 577 enhancement of the catalytic performance of Z-nZVFe-Cu. Hence, Z-nZVFe-Cu 578 provides a promising advantage for the remediation of TCE contaminated 579 groundwater. 580

metadata.abstractText: 15 Zeolite supported nano zero valent iron copper bimetallic composite (Z-nZVFe16 Cu) was synthesized using an ion exchange method. The morphology and physico17 chemical properties of the Z-nZVFe-Cu composite were determined using 18 transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), 19 Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET), Energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS), Fourier 20 transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and X-ray diffractometer (XRD). The results 21 showed that iron and copper nano particles were well dispersed on the zeolite sheet. 22 The degradation efficiency of trichloroethylene (TCE) achieved was more than 95% 23 using Z-nZVFe-Cu as a heterogeneous Fenton like catalyst. An efficient removal of 24 total organic carbon (TOC) was promoted as compared to zeolite supported iron nano 25 composite (Z-nZVFe) and unsupported nano iron (nZVFe). Electron spin resonance 26 (ESR) detection confirmed the intensity of hydroxyl radicals (OH) in the system. 27 While benzoic acid (BA), a probe indicator for the quantification of OH, 28
